bfgs2_test.cpp

Minimizes function "func" by using a modified Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno-algorithm. Given a function func of N variables, from which the gradient or first partial derivatives at arbitrary points can be computed and which can be locally approximated by the quadratic form of equation

then the number of unknown parameters in is equal to the number of free parameters in and , which is . To gather information about these parameters, function evaluations and line minimizations are used. BFGS as a variable metric method builds up, iteratively, a good approximation to the inverse Hessian matrix , that is, to construct a sequence of matrices with the property,

The number of iterations can be restricted.

Parameters:
p N-dimensional initial starting point.
gtol Convergence requirement on zeoring the gradient.
iter Number of iterations that were performed by the function.
fret Minimum value of the function.
func The function that will be minimized.
dfunc The derivation of func.
iterMax Max. number of allowed iterations.
linmintype Type of algorithm used for line minimization, possible values are LNSRCH for lnsrch, CBLNSRCH for cblnsrch, LINMIN for linmin and DERIVLINMIN for dlinmin .
Returns:
none.
Please follow the link to view the source code of the example. The example can be executed in the example directory of package LinAlg.

Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1995
Changes
none
Status
stable
See also:
lnsrch.cpp, cblnsrch.cpp, linmin.cpp, dlinmin.cpp, bfgs.cpp

00053 #include <iostream>
00054 #include "Array/ArrayIo.h"
00055 #include "LinAlg/arrayoptimize.h"
00056 
00057 using namespace std;
00058 
00059 // The testfunction: 
00060 double testfunc(const Array< double >& x)
00061 {
00062     return x(0) * x(0) + 2;
00063 }
00064 
00065 
00066 // The derivation of the testfunction: 
00067 void dtestfunc(const Array< double >& x, Array< double >& y)
00068 {
00069     y = 2*x(0);
00070     return;
00071 }
00072 
00073 
00074 int main()
00075 {
00076     double          fret(0.),      // minimum of the function
00077                     gtol(0.);      // convergence requirement
00078     unsigned        iter(0),       // no. of iterations performed
00079                                    // by the bfgs-function
00080                     iterMax(200),  // max. number of allowed iterations
00081                     i;             // counter value
00082     Array< double > p(1),          // initial starting point
00083                     xi(1);         // search direction
00084 
00085 
00086     cout << "Performing minimization for function f(x) = x*x + 2 "
00087          << "with starting point (-3,11) and direction (3,11):" << endl 
00088          << endl;
00089 
00090     // Perform minimization with all four line minimization
00091     // algorithms as subroutines:
00092     for (i = 0; i < 4; i++)
00093     {
00094         // Initialize starting point and search direction:
00095         p(0) = -3.;
00096         xi(0) = 3.;
00097 
00098         // Output of subroutine types:
00099         switch( i ) {
00100             case 0 : cout << "Using linesearch as subroutine:" << endl;
00101                      break;
00102             case 1 : cout << "Using cubelinesearch as subroutine:" << endl;
00103                      break;
00104             case 2 : cout << "Using linear minimization as subroutine:" 
00105                           << endl;
00106                      break;
00107             case 3 : cout << "Using derived linear minimization as "
00108                           << "subroutine:" << endl;
00109                      break;
00110         }
00111       
00112         // Minimization of test function:
00113         bfgs2(p, gtol, iter, fret, testfunc, dtestfunc, iterMax, 
00114              (LinMinTypes) i);
00115 
00116         // Output of results:
00117         cout << "current starting point = point where function " 
00118              << "takes it minimum value:" << endl;
00119         writeArray(p, cout);
00120         cout << "minimum of function:" << endl;
00121         cout << fret << endl;   
00122         cout << "number of iterations performed:" << endl;
00123         cout << iter << endl;
00124         cout << endl << endl;
00125 
00126     }
00127 
00128     return 0;
00129 }
